Posts.title: Oldest University Town
Posts.author: Tiina Kask
Posts.body: Tartu is home to the University of Tartu, which was founded in 1632. It's one of the oldest and most prestigious universities in Northern Europe, making Tartu a hub for education and academia.

Posts.title: Hansatic League History
Posts.author: Andrus Kivi
Posts.body: Tartu has a rich history as a member of the Hanseatic League, a medieval trading organization. This historical connection is reflected in the city's architecture and culture, making it a unique destination for history enthusiasts.

Posts.title: Emaj천gi River
Posts.author: Karina J천gi
Posts.body: The Emaj천gi River flows through Tartu, and it's the second-longest river in Estonia. The river and its scenic banks are a popular place for outdoor activities, picnics, and enjoying the natural beauty of the area.

Posts.title: Estonian National Museum
Posts.author: John Doe
Posts.body: The Estonian National Museum, located in Tartu, is a modern and engaging museum that showcases the history and culture of Estonia. It's a must-visit for anyone interested in learning about the country's heritage.

Posts.title: Interesting School Fact #1
Posts.author: Karl Sein
Posts.body: Did you know that the first public school in the United States, Boston Latin School, was founded in 1635?

Posts.title: Fun School Fact #2
Posts.author: Kristjan Meri
Posts.body: In Japan, students clean their own classrooms and school facilities. This practice is called 'o-soji.'

Posts.title: Amazing School Fact #3
Posts.author: Kristjan Meri
Posts.body: The largest school in the world is City Montessori School in Lucknow, India, with over 56,000 students!

Posts.title: Educational Fact #4
Posts.author: Karl Sein
Posts.body: The world's oldest existing and continually operating educational institution is the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Morocco, founded in 859 AD.

Posts.title: School Trivia #5
Posts.author: Karl Sein
Posts.body: Some schools in Finland have no homework, and students have shorter school days. It's one of the world's most successful education systems.

Posts.title: Did You Know #6
Posts.author: Andrus Kivi
Posts.body: Albert Einstein was once a student, just like us! He attended the Luitpold Gymnasium in Munich, Germany.
